title: 1Ti 1:15
content: Jesus purpose is to save sinners including but not stopping with us.

title: 1Ti 1:16
content: "So that" states purpose. He saved us in order to save others.

title: 1Ti 1:12
content: Jesus directly appoints us for His purpose. What is the purpose?

title: 1Ti 2:7
content: Paul's purpose was to reach the Gentiles, us, who at that point were the lost.

title: 1Ti 6:17
content: We who are rich are instructed to exchange that for rich works which then result in riches in heaven.  He provides these things to us for this purpose.  This also contains a warning that I think means that if we thought He gave to us for ourselves we are arrogant. The first shall be last.

title: 1Ti 6:9
content: Strong warning!  Desire for wealth beyond basics is a temptation which will ruin us!

title: 1Ti 6:7
content: If we have stuff left that we have not invested we will be held accountable and will lose it forever.

title: 1Ti 6:10
content: Welt.h not invested leads us away from life not toward it.

title: 1Ti 6:11
content: Those seeking godliness should actively flee from being ruled by wealth.

title: 1Ti 4:11
content: Paul commands Timothy to command others to imitate him who imitates Paul who is a slave of Christ for the purpose of reaching all. This leaves no believer free to do as he wishes.

title: 1Ti 4:10
content: We have committed and gambled on the God whose intent is to save all men. Therefore that is our purpose as well.

title: 1Ti 2:6
content: If Jesus gave everything can we give less?

title: 1Ti 2:4
content:
Strong and repeated statement of God and Jesus statement of purpose.

1 Peter 3:9

title: 1Ti 1:1
content: Paul's only claim to fame here is that he has a mandatory purpose given by God.  He is now passing that purpose on to Timothy

title: 2010 Spring teaching schedule
Hui Bible - TianJing
content: From G For the past several years a group of translators have been working an adaptation of the Chinese Bible into a version contextualized for the Hui. Praise God, the good news is the adaptation is completed and the first printing has taken place. How we are working to get the Word in country and distributed. Please pray God will open door as we begin to distribute the Hui Bible. You can see it at www.tianjing.org Tian Jing is what the Hui call the New Testament

title: GO 2010 Sunday 1 message
content: In 1949, a young student at Wheaton College penned some words in his private journal that expressed the growing passion of his heart. Seven years later, he would lie dead, along with his four companions, on a small beach in the Amazon jungles of Ecuador, murdered by the head-hunting tribe of natives that outsiders called the Aucas. The words in his journal were these: “He is no fool who gives what he cannot keep, to gain what he cannot loose.” What kind of man gives his life in an attempt to reach killers with the Gospel of love, knowing full well that he is risking leaving his wife and child without a husband or father? Who would do such a thing? Was Jim Elliot so other worldly, so spiritual, that you and I can’t even identify with him? Listen to the words that his wife, Elizabeth, wrote in the preface to her biography of her husband, “Shadow of the Almighty.” “Jim’s aim was to know God. His course, obedience. He and the other men with whom he died were hailed as heroes, “martyrs.” I do not approve. Nor would they have approved. Is the distinction between living for Christ and dying for Him, after all, so great? Is not the second the logical conclusion of the first? “ I was struck with that thought. Of course, the Bible teaches that one must lose his life to find it, that one must die to self and live for Christ. But to actually lay down your life, to die, do I really believe that that would be a logical conclusion of my commitment to live for Christ. When rioting broke out last year in a city in East Asia where Grace has placed a team of 9 young people from this church with the mission agency called Pioneers, there were days I would sit in my office and stare at the phone and argue with God about what I should do. Should I make that call to Pioneers and tell them that we are extracting the team from that city? Should I pressure Pioneers to make that call? How long should I wait? How long could I wait? What if they were overrun with the violence and killed? Could I live with myself if I didn’t make that call? More than once I reached for the phone only to change my mind at the last second. What makes these kids choose to live in a place like that? What makes us here at Grace send our children to places like that? Over the last six years, since I took the position of Pastor of Global Outreach here at Grace, we, you and I, as a family, we have invested right at $ dollars in placing and keeping people like this team, in Turkey, in Greece, in the inner city of Austin, Texas, in the Middle East, and in India, just to name a few. They serve the Hispanic community, the Native Americans, on the Refugee Highway, university students, international students and the homeless. That is how we have chosen to invest some of our wealth. That’s enough money to . Why? Why would we do that? Turn in your Bibles to Luke 7:36 - Walk with me into Simon, the Pharisee’s, home. On that day, Simon has invited a very special guest to dine with him. Jesus was there. Now, we don’t know why Simon had invited him. We don’t know if it was part of a strategy by the Jews to find a way to discredit Jesus, or if Simon was truly curious, or if he was motivated by personal status, or what. But as we enter the room, we see the men all reclined around Simon’s table sharing a meal together and exchanging polite conversation with one another. Out of nowhere, a woman appeared at the door to the dinning area. She took a hesitant step into the room and looked around. As she became the center of attention and all conversation ceased, she felt the death sentence fall on her head. This was an affront to Simon that would not go unpunished. As she looked up, she was met by the twinkle of anticipation in the eyes of the man she had come to see. Jesus waited quietly never taking his eyes off of the new arrival. Now her resolve took over. No longer self-conscious, totally focused on Jesus, and feeling the emotions begin to surge through her she quietly walked to where he was reclined. She knelt down at his feet, the tears now freely flowing down her face, and gently removed his sandals. Her tears fell on his dusty feet, and as she wept she took her loose hair and began to wipe his feet clean and dry them. The only sound in the room was her sobs. Then she took out an alabaster flask of perfumed oil, she broke the bottle open and she poured it liberally over his feet, filling the whole house with the sweet aroma. Simon was indignant. Verse 39 says, “Now when the Pharisee who had invited Him saw this, he spoke to himself, saying, “This Man, if He were a prophet, would know who and what manner of woman this is who is touching Him, for she is a sinner.” Jesus eyes caught Simon’s and he said, “Simon, I’ve got something to say to you. A creditor had two guys who owed him but couldn’t pay. One owed him fifty dollars, the other owed five thousand dollars. So the creditor freely forgave them both. Which one of them would love him more.” Simon said, “Well, I suppose the one who was forgiven more would love more.” Jesus said, “You have judged rightly.” Now, lets take a break from the story and ask ourselves, what was the difference between Simon and this prostitute whose name we don’t even know? Was it that one had sinned a whole bunch, and the other had just sinned a little bit? Or maybe the difference was the kind of sin they had committed. After all, isn’t prostitution much worse than, say, pride? No. I don’t think so. The difference between the two was not quality or quantity. The difference between them was their perception of their sin. The woman had looked herself in the mirror and had freely admitted that she was so indebted to God, that there was no way she could ever pay her way out. She had sinned much. She knew it and she was resigned to her fate. In fact, she probably thought this was the last day of her life. She most likely assumed that what waited her for this unthinkable interruption in the house of this Pharisee was death by stoning. Simon, on the other hand, had looked in the mirror and said, “I’m a pretty good guy, and thank you Lord that I am not like other men. I tithe, I fast, I pray, what’s not to like?” Do you see that? It is the perception that naturally leads to the response of each character. Perception = response This woman had sinned much, true enough. But she was willing to look at herself in a mirror called “truth”. By this point she had given up on making excuses and on blaming others. She would die, but not without letting Jesus know how she felt about him. Simon had looked in a “carnival” mirror. Not one of those that distorts your body. No, no. This carnival mirror is self-created from the lies he had listened to form the culture around him and his own sinful heart. These mirrors only shows us at our very best. And because he had bought into the lie that the mirror was showing him, he was totally self-deceived. How we see ourselves directly affects how we love and serve God. A true mirror will always lead to a heart of gratitude and a life of service. A carnival mirror leads to taking things for granted, even God. The degree to which you agree with God about who you really are, to that degree will you worship and serve Him. Either you will look into the mirror of truth, and you will bow in worship and get up to serve, or the “carnival” mirror will make you look good in your own eyes and make God look common. Mirror of Truth = worship + service Carnival mirror = I’m lookin’ good + God look’s common Look how Jesus assesses this response from Simon starting in chapter 7 verse 44. 44 Then He turned to the woman and said to Simon, “Do you see this woman? I entered your house; you gave Me no water for My feet, but she has washed My feet with her tears and wiped them with the hair of her head. 45 You gave Me no kiss, but this woman has not ceased to kiss My feet since the time she came in. 46 You did not anoint My head with oil, but this woman has anointed My feet with fragrant oil. 47 Therefore I say to you, her sins, which are many, are forgiven, for she loved much. But to whom little is forgiven, the same loves little.” 48 Then He said to her, “Your sins are forgiven.” 49 And those who sat at the table with Him began to say to themselves, “Who is this who even forgives sins?” 50 Then He said to the woman, “Your faith has saved you. Go in peace.” I can only imagine the stunned look on her face. I can see her mouth drop open and tears pool in her eyes once again, this time it wasn’t tears of repentance, it was a tears of inexpressible joy. She had come into Jesus presence holding out an empty thimble hoping against hope for a comforting word, some encouragement perhaps before she died. Jesus opened the flood gates of heaven, and poured out on her a waterfall of mercy and grace. Sins forgiven? Saved?? Are you kidding me!!!! She would actually walk out of Simon’s house and not face death for her intrusion. She would walk out forgiven. Now when she looked in the mirror of truth, she would see a new woman, a woman saved by Jesus grace and mercy. I’m betting that this woman was never the same. I’m betting that she never got over those words, forgiven and saved. I’m betting that she lived her life compelled out of the incredible overflow of God’s love for her expressed in Christ Jesus. I could see her sharing that love everywhere she went from that day on, across her street and around the world, she would go where Jesus led her. If asked, she would go to a remote city in East Asia. She had exchanged what she could not keep, her very life, for what she could never lose, forgiveness and a new life. Do you suppose that this might be why Jim Elliot died on a landing strip in Ecuador or why our sons and daughters end up in East Asia? Are these young people BIG sinners? You bet they are!! You know how I know that? Because we are all BIG, HUGE sinners, that’s how. They are huge sinners who have been forgiven much and so, they love much. It’s all about perception. It’s about the mirror you choose to look in. At Grace, we don’t do Global Outreach because we love God. We do Global Outreach for the love from God. It hasn’t always been that way. Not here at Grace. Not in my life. It usually takes an act of God’s mercy to get our attention enough to realize that we are using a “carnival” mirror and believing it to be true. God has graciously smashed several carnival mirrors that I have allowed to deceive me. Every time it happened I have my spiritual breath knocked out of me, but Jesus always helped me to my knees and whispered to me, “learn from me for I am humble and meek and you will find rest for your soul.” What mirror are you looking at yourself in? There was a time when the Apostle Paul, still known as Saul, was looking at his reflection in a “carnival” mirror. Much later in his life, he would look back on those days and reminisce about that image of himself. In Philippians 3:4-6 he says, “I also might have confidence in the flesh. If anyone else thinks he may have confidence in the flesh, I more so: 5 circumcised the eighth day, of the stock of Israel, of the tribe of Benjamin, a Hebrew of the Hebrews; concerning the law, a Pharisee; 6 concerning zeal, persecuting the church; concerning the righteousness which is in the law, blameless.” What would drive this same man, to repeatedly subject himself to mistreatments like stoning and beatings and ship wrecks and prison for the sake of the gospel? What would bring him from thinking he was God’s greatest gift to mankind to saying something like, “When I preach the gospel, I cannot boast, for I am compelled to preach,” in I Corinthians 9:16. I’m sure Paul had a variety of motivations for what he did. We are complex creatures motivated by a lot of things. But I think there is a foundation based on a life experience for this dramatic change. I think it happened one day when Saul, full of self righteous indignation, gripping in his hand an order given to him by the Jewish Sanhedrine, fuming with anger over what he perceived to be the perversion of all that he believed and lived for, these upstart Jesus followers, found himself flat on his back, knocked from his horse, staring up at a vision of the risen Christ. The Christ spoke, “Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me.” In utter astonishment, he asked, “Lord, who are you?” “I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting.” In that second, Saul’s death sentence was signed and sealed. Trembling and astonished, Saul, soon to be Paul, asked, “Lord, what do YOU want me to do?” Now, we might think that an encounter with Jesus like that would provide life long motivation for any of us. But I don’t think that the encounter itself is what compelled Paul. I think what compelled this man was the fact that after this experience, he was still alive!!! This self-described chief of all sinners, this persecutor of the church, this murderer of saints, was still alive!!! How could this be? “I am still alive! No, more than that, I’m brand newly born. Where I deserve death, I have life. More than that, I have been counted worthy to carry this Gospel to the gentiles. What is this waterfall of grace that I am standing under? My eyes were blinded and I was expecting annihilation. Instead, God showers me with his mercy, his love, his grace.” So, he would go on to say in Philippians 3:7 and 8 7”But what things were gain to me, these I have counted loss for Christ. 8 Yet indeed I also count all things loss for the excellence of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord, for whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and count them as rubbish, that I may gain Christ.” Paul was motivated, compelled, driven by the absolute overflow of God’s love and grace that he woke to every day of his life after his Damascus road encounter. My dear family, this is what aught to compel us as well. At Grace, we do Global Outreach for the love from God. I trust that we as a body, and each one of us as individuals, are not deluded into thinking that we are gaining brownie points with God through missions or any other form of service, nor that we are saving the world, nor that we are hastening the second coming of Christ. I trust that, like the woman who cried on Jesus feet, like Paul who celebrated life knowing he should be dead, we are acutely aware of the depths of our own rebellion against the Lord. It doesn’t always take getting knocked off a horse to come to this realization, but it almost always takes something very like that. At some point, if you haven’t yet, you will find yourself flat on your back looking up at the risen Christ. What is your response? I trust that you, like Paul, will find yourself eternally grateful that, while we cowered in a corner, Jesus reached down with his life, death and resurrection, and poured out a flood of cleansing grace and mercy over our retched and useless lives. We are born again into newness of life, made co-participators of the divine nature, baptized into Christ’s body, and indwelt by the Holy Spirit. How can that not compel us to be the best that we can be and give the best that we are in a love offering to this amazing God? Remember that phone call I was struggling over making to extract our team from the troubled East Asia city? I realized I didn’t make that phone call to Pioneers, because those young people that are out there don’t belong to me. They were released to God. They are exchanging that which they cannot keep, for that which they cannot lose. How could I take that away from them? There is no sacrifice in that. Are you making that exchange with your choices? Don’t settle for your image in a carnival mirror. Please don’t. It might make you look good, but it is a lie from the pit. Look into the mirror of truth that is the person and word of Jesus Christ. Be compelled with the wonder that you are still alive. You shouldn’t be, you know. You really shouldn’t. But if you can feel the waterfall of God’s mercy and grace cascading down on you, then I think you will find a way to celebrate that on a world stage. You will find a way to involve yourself in God’s purposes for the nations. That road of service, whatever it looks like, whether it is praying, or giving or going, will be driven by many things, but primarily it will be driven by the love from God.

title: Nicene creed
content:
The Nicene Creed


I believe in one God, the Father Almighty, Maker of heaven and earth, and of all things visible and invisible.


And in one Lord Jesus Christ, the only-begotten Son of God, begotten of the Father before all worlds; God of God, Light of Light, very God of very God; begotten, not made, being of one substance with the Father, by whom all things were made.


Who, for us men and for our salvation, came down from heaven, and was incarnate by the Holy Spirit of the virgin Mary, and was made man; and was crucified also for us under Pontius Pilate; He suffered and was buried; and the third day He rose again, according to the Scriptures; and ascended into heaven, and sits on the right hand of the Father; and He shall come again, with glory, to judge the quick and the dead; whose kingdom shall have no end.


And I believe in the Holy Ghost, the Lord and Giver of Life; who proceeds from the Father and the Son; who with the Father and the Son together is worshipped and glorified; who spoke by the prophets.


And I believe in one holy catholic and apostolic Church. I acknowledge one baptism for the remission of sins; and I look for the resurrection of the dead, and the life of the world to come. Amen.

Evokes intimacy of dwelling, God's presence among the Nation in the wilderness, and God's shekina glory leading them through the wilderness.
He “tabernacled” with us

title: Jn 1:14 Word became flesh
content:
He who created everything crawled inside weak human flesh to condescend to us.
V1 expresses the eternal (eliminate, hn) timeless existence of the Word, Christ's diety foremost.  This verse extends that by saying that in time, the eternal became temporal flesh in the person of Jesus.   He is both fully God and fully man.

content: The great and profound mysterious Creator in all His glory and holiness is now standing there in the flesh. By looking very closely at Jesus and His deeds and words we can see all we need to know about God.

title: Jn 3:16 NET
content: For this is the way God loved the world: He gave his one and only Son, so that everyone who believes in him will not perish but have eternal life. 17 For God did not send his Son into the world to condemn the world, but that the world should be saved through him. 18 The one who believes in him is not condemned. The one who does not believe has been condemned already, because he has not believed in the name of the one and only Son of God. 19 Now this is the basis for judging: that the light has come into the world and people loved the darkness rather than the light, because their deeds were evil. 20 For everyone who does evil deeds hates the light and does not come to the light, so that their deeds will not be exposed. 21 But the one who practices the truth comes to the light, so that it may be plainly evident

title: "The fatal habit of considering Christian morals as distinct from Christian doctrines insensibly gained strength. Thus the peculiar doctrines of Christianity went more and more out of sight, and as might naturally have been expected, the moral system itse
content:
The fatal habit of considering Christian morals as distinct from Christian doctrines insensibly gained strength. Thus the peculiar doctrines of Christianity went more and more out of sight, and as might naturally have been expected, the moral system itself also began to wither and decay, being robbed of that which should have supplied it with life and nutriment.
- William Wilberforce
associated_product: Amazing Grace in the Life of William Wilberforce (Foreword by Jonathan Aitken)

title: "Wouldn't that definition of sin be good for society? But Wilberforce says, "Their slight notions of the guilt and evil of sin [reveal] an utter [lack] of all suitable reverence for the Divine Majesty. This principle [reverence for the Divine Majesty] is
content: Wouldn't that definition of sin be good for society? But Wilberforce says, "Their slight notions of the guilt and evil of sin [reveal] an utter [lack] of all suitable reverence for the Divine Majesty. This principle [reverence for the Divine Majesty] is justly termed in Scripture, 'The beginning of wis dom' [Ps. 111: 10]." 12 And without this wisdom, there will be no deep and lasting good done for man, spiritually or politi cally. Therefore, the supremacy of God's glory in all things is what he calls "the grand governing maxim" in all of life. 13 The good of society may never be put ahead of this. That would dishonor God and, paradoxically, defeat the good of society. For the good of society, the good of society must not be the primary good
associated_product: Amazing Grace in the Life of William Wilberforce (Foreword by Jonathan Aitken)

title: "Simplicity and generosity were the mark of his life. Much later, after he was married, he wrote, "By careful manage ment, I should be able to give at least one-quarter of my income to the poor." 5 His sons reported that before he mar ried he was giving a
content: Simplicity and generosity were the mark of his life. Much later, after he was married, he wrote, "By careful manage ment, I should be able to give at least one- quarter of my income to the poor." 5 His sons reported that before he mar ried he was giving away well over a fourth of his income, one year actually giving away £ 3,000 more than he made. He wrote that riches were, "considering them as in themselves, acceptable, but, from the infirmity of [our] nature, as highly dangerous possessions; and [we are to value] them chiefly not as instruments of luxury or splendor, but as affording the means of honoring [our] heavenly Benefactor, and lessen ing the miseries of mankind." 6 This was the way his mind worked: Everything in politics was for the alleviation of mis ery and the spread of happiness
associated_product: Amazing Grace in the Life of William Wilberforce (Foreword by Jonathan Aitken)

title: "Seeds were sown almost immediately at the beginning of his Christian life, it seems, of the later passion to help the poor and to turn all his inherited wealth and his naturally high station into a means of blessing the oppressed." Amazing Grace - Chapte

title: ""Next to the Slave Trade, I have long thought our making no effort to introduce the blessings of religious and moral improvement among our subjects in the East, the greatest of our national crimes." 8 Seven years later "Wilberforce . . . enthralled the H
content: "Next to the Slave Trade, I have long thought our making no effort to introduce the blessings of religious and moral improvement among our subjects in the East, the greatest of our national crimes." 8 Seven years later "Wilberforce... enthralled the House... with the cause of Christian mis sions in India." 9 The Englishman William Carey had to live in Serampore, a Danish enclave in India, until Wilberforce triumphed in 1813 when the prohibition of evangelism in British colonies in India was lifted by the East India Company Charter, which now guaranteed liberty to propagate the Christian Faith. "Parliament had opened a fast- locked door and it was Wilberforce who had turned the key, in a speech which Lord Erskine said 'deserves a place in the library of every man of letters, even if he were an atheist

content:
There were great battles in the soul as well as in Parliament. For example, in March 1788, after a serious struggle with colitis he seemed to enter into a "dark night of the soul." "Corrupt imaginations are perpetually rising in my mind and innumerable fears close me in on every side." 21 We get a glimpse of how he fought for joy in these times from what he wrote in his notebook of prayers:
Lord, thou knowest that no strength, wisdom or contriv ance of human power can signify, or relieve me. It is in thy power alone to deliver me. I fly to thee for succor and support, O Lord let it come speedily; give

content: From G   For the past several years a group of translators have been working an adaptation of the Chinese Bible into a version contextualized for the Hui.  Praise God, the good news is the adaptation is completed and the first printing has taken place.  How we are working to get the Word in country and distributed.  Please pray God will open door as we begin to distribute the Hui Bible.  You can see it at www.tianjing.org  Tian Jing is what the Hui call the New Testament

title: GO 2010 Sunday 1 message
content: In 1949, a young student at Wheaton College penned some words in his private journal that expressed the growing passion of his heart.  Seven years later, he would lie dead, along with his four companions, on a small beach in the Amazon jungles of Ecuador, murdered by the head-hunting tribe of natives that outsiders called the Aucas.  The words in his journal were these: “He is no fool who gives what he cannot keep, to gain what he cannot loose.” What kind of man gives his life in an attempt to reach killers with the Gospel of love, knowing full well that he is risking leaving his wife and child without a husband or father?  Who would do such a thing?  Was Jim Elliot so other worldly, so spiritual, that you and I can’t even identify with him?  Listen to the words that his wife, Elizabeth, wrote in the preface to her biography of her husband, “Shadow of the Almighty.” “Jim’s aim was to know God.  His course, obedience.  He and the other men with whom he died were hailed as heroes, “martyrs.”  I do not approve.  Nor would they have approved. Is the distinction between living for Christ and dying for Him, after all, so great?  Is not the second the logical conclusion of the first? “ I was struck with that thought.  Of course, the Bible teaches that one must lose his life to find it, that one must die to self and live for Christ.  But to actually lay down your life, to die, do I really believe that that would be a logical conclusion of my commitment to live for Christ. When rioting broke out last year in a city in East Asia where Grace has placed a team of 9 young people from this church with the mission agency called Pioneers, there were days I would sit in my office and stare at the phone and argue with God about what I should do.  Should I make that call to Pioneers and tell them that we are extracting the team from that city?  Should I pressure Pioneers to make that call?  How long should I wait?  How long could I wait?  What if they were overrun with the violence and killed?  Could I live with myself if I didn’t make that call?   More than once I reached for the phone only to change my mind at the last second.  What makes these kids choose to live in a place like that?  What makes us here at Grace send our children to places like that?   Over the last six years, since I took the position of Pastor of Global Outreach here at Grace, we, you and I, as a family, we have invested right at $ dollars in placing and keeping people like this team, in Turkey, in Greece, in the inner city of Austin, Texas, in the Middle East, and in India, just to name a few. They serve the Hispanic community, the Native Americans, on the Refugee Highway, university students, international students and the homeless. That is how we have chosen to invest some of our wealth.  That’s enough money to      .  Why?  Why would we do that? Turn in your Bibles to Luke 7:36 -  Walk with me into Simon, the Pharisee’s, home.  On that day, Simon has invited a very special guest to dine with him.  Jesus was there.  Now, we don’t know why Simon had invited him.  We don’t know if it was part of a strategy by the Jews to find a way to discredit Jesus, or if Simon was truly curious, or if he was motivated by personal status, or what.   But as we enter the room, we see the men all reclined around Simon’s table sharing a meal together and exchanging polite conversation with one another. Out of nowhere, a woman appeared at the door to the dinning area. She took a hesitant step into the room and looked around.  As she became the center of attention and all conversation ceased, she felt the death sentence fall on her head.  This was an affront to Simon that would not go unpunished. As she looked up, she was met by the twinkle of anticipation in the eyes of the man she had come to see.  Jesus waited quietly never taking his eyes off of the new arrival. Now her resolve took over.  No longer self-conscious, totally focused on Jesus, and feeling the emotions begin to surge through her she quietly walked to where he was reclined. She knelt down at his feet, the tears now freely flowing down her face, and gently removed his sandals.  Her tears fell on his dusty feet, and as she wept she took her loose hair and began to wipe his feet clean and dry them.  The only sound in the room was her sobs. Then she took out an alabaster flask of perfumed oil, she broke the bottle open and she poured it liberally over his feet, filling the whole house with the sweet aroma. Simon was indignant.  Verse 39 says, “Now when the Pharisee who had invited Him saw this, he spoke to himself, saying, “This Man, if He were a prophet, would know who and what manner of woman this is who is touching Him, for she is a sinner.”  Jesus eyes caught Simon’s and he said, “Simon, I’ve got something to say to you.  A creditor had two guys who owed him but couldn’t pay.  One owed him fifty dollars, the other owed five thousand dollars.  So the creditor freely forgave them both.  Which one of them would love him more.” Simon said, “Well, I suppose the one who was forgiven more would love more.”  Jesus said, “You have judged rightly.” Now, lets take a break from the story and ask ourselves, what was the difference between Simon and this prostitute whose name we don’t even know?  Was it that one had sinned a whole bunch, and the other had just sinned a little bit?  Or maybe the difference was the kind of sin they had committed.  After all, isn’t prostitution much worse than, say, pride?  No.  I don’t think so. The difference between the two was not quality or quantity. The difference between them was their perception of their sin.   The woman had looked herself in the mirror and had freely admitted that she was so indebted to God, that there was no way she could ever pay her way out.  She had sinned much.  She knew it and she was resigned to her fate.  In fact, she probably thought this was the last day of her life.  She most likely assumed that what waited her for this unthinkable interruption in the house of this Pharisee was death by stoning.   Simon, on the other hand, had looked in the mirror and said, “I’m a pretty good guy, and thank you Lord that I am not like other men.  I tithe, I fast, I pray, what’s not to like?” Do you see that?  It is the perception that naturally leads to the response of each character. Perception = response This woman had sinned much, true enough.  But she was willing to look at herself in a mirror called “truth”.  By this point she had given up on making excuses and on blaming others.  She would die, but not without letting Jesus know how she felt about him. Simon had looked in a “carnival” mirror.  Not one of those that distorts your body.  No, no.  This carnival mirror is self-created from the lies he had listened to form the culture around him and his own sinful heart.  These mirrors only shows us at our very best.  And because he had bought into the lie that the mirror was showing him, he was totally self-deceived. How we see ourselves directly affects how we love and serve God.  A true mirror will always lead to a heart of gratitude and a life of service.   A carnival mirror leads to taking things for granted, even God. The degree to which you agree with God about who you really are, to that degree will you worship and serve Him. Either you will look into the mirror of truth, and you will bow in worship and get up to serve, or the “carnival” mirror will make you look good in your own eyes and make God look common. Mirror of Truth = worship + service Carnival mirror = I’m lookin’ good + God look’s common Look how Jesus assesses this response from Simon starting in chapter 7 verse 44. 44 Then He turned to the woman and said to Simon, “Do you see this woman? I entered your house; you gave Me no water for My feet, but she has washed My feet with her tears and wiped them with the hair of her head. 45 You gave Me no kiss, but this woman has not ceased to kiss My feet since the time she came in. 46 You did not anoint My head with oil, but this woman has anointed My feet with fragrant oil. 47 Therefore I say to you, her sins, which are many, are forgiven, for she loved much. But to whom little is forgiven, the same loves little.” 48 Then He said to her, “Your sins are forgiven.” 49 And those who sat at the table with Him began to say to themselves, “Who is this who even forgives sins?” 50 Then He said to the woman, “Your faith has saved you. Go in peace.” I can only imagine the stunned look on her face.  I can see her mouth drop open and tears pool in her eyes once again, this time it wasn’t tears of repentance, it was a tears of inexpressible joy. She had come into Jesus presence holding out an empty thimble hoping against hope for a comforting word, some encouragement perhaps before she died.  Jesus opened the flood gates of heaven, and poured out on her a waterfall of mercy and grace.  Sins forgiven?  Saved??  Are you kidding me!!!!  She would actually walk out of Simon’s house and not face death for her intrusion.  She would walk out forgiven.  Now when she looked in the mirror of truth, she would see a new woman, a woman saved by Jesus grace and mercy. I’m betting that this woman was never the same.  I’m betting that she never got over those words, forgiven and saved.  I’m betting that she lived her life compelled out of the incredible overflow of God’s love for her expressed in Christ Jesus.  I could see her sharing that love everywhere she went from that day on, across her street and around the world, she would go where Jesus led her.  If asked, she would go to a remote city in East Asia. She had exchanged what she could not keep, her very life, for what she could never lose, forgiveness and a new life. Do you suppose that this might be why Jim Elliot died on a landing strip in Ecuador or why our sons and daughters end up in East Asia?  Are these young people BIG sinners?  You bet they are!!  You know how I know that?  Because we are all BIG, HUGE sinners, that’s how. They are huge sinners who have been forgiven much and so, they love much.   It’s all about perception.  It’s about the mirror you choose to look in.   At Grace, we don’t do Global Outreach because we love God. We do Global Outreach for the love from God.   It hasn’t always been that way.  Not here at Grace. Not in my life.  It usually takes an act of God’s mercy to get our attention enough to realize that we are using a “carnival” mirror and believing it to be true.  God has graciously smashed several carnival mirrors that I have allowed to deceive me.  Every time it happened I have my spiritual breath knocked out of me, but Jesus always helped me to my knees and whispered to me, “learn from me for I am humble and meek and you will find rest for your soul.”   What mirror are you looking at yourself in? There was a time when the Apostle Paul, still known as Saul, was looking at his reflection in a “carnival” mirror.  Much later in his life, he would look back on those days and reminisce about that image of himself.   In Philippians 3:4-6 he says, “I also might have confidence in the flesh. If anyone else thinks he may have confidence in the flesh, I more so: 5 circumcised the eighth day, of the stock of Israel, of the tribe of Benjamin, a Hebrew of the Hebrews; concerning the law, a Pharisee; 6 concerning zeal, persecuting the church; concerning the righteousness which is in the law, blameless.” What would drive this same man, to repeatedly subject himself to mistreatments like stoning and beatings and ship wrecks and prison for the sake of the gospel?  What would bring him from thinking he was God’s greatest gift to mankind to saying something like, “When I preach the gospel, I cannot boast, for I am compelled to preach,” in I Corinthians 9:16. I’m sure Paul had a variety of motivations for what he did.  We are complex creatures motivated by a lot of things. But I think there is a foundation based on a life experience for this dramatic change.  I think it happened one day when Saul, full of self righteous indignation, gripping in his hand an order given to him by the Jewish Sanhedrine, fuming with anger over what he perceived to be the perversion of all that he believed and lived for, these upstart Jesus followers, found himself flat on his back, knocked from his horse, staring up at a vision of the risen Christ.  The Christ spoke, “Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me.” In utter astonishment, he asked, “Lord, who are you?”  “I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting.”  In that second, Saul’s death sentence was signed and sealed. Trembling and astonished, Saul, soon to be Paul, asked, “Lord, what do YOU want me to do?”   Now, we might think that an encounter with Jesus like that would provide life long motivation for any of us.  But I don’t think that the encounter itself is what compelled Paul.  I think what compelled this man was the fact that after this experience, he was still alive!!!  This self-described chief of all sinners, this persecutor of the church, this murderer of saints, was still alive!!!  How could this be?   “I am still alive!  No, more than that, I’m brand newly born.  Where I deserve death, I have life.  More than that, I have been counted worthy to carry this Gospel to the gentiles.  What is this waterfall of grace that I am standing under?  My eyes were blinded and I was expecting annihilation.  Instead, God showers me with his mercy, his love, his grace.”   So, he would go on to say in Philippians 3:7 and 8 7”But what things were gain to me, these I have counted loss for Christ. 8 Yet indeed I also count all things loss for the excellence of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord, for whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and count them as rubbish, that I may gain Christ.” Paul was motivated, compelled, driven by the absolute overflow of God’s love and grace that he woke to every day of his life after his Damascus road encounter. My dear family, this is what aught to compel us as well.  At Grace, we do Global Outreach for the love from God.  I trust that we as a body, and each one of us as individuals, are not deluded into thinking that we are gaining brownie points with God through missions or any other form of service, nor that we are saving the world, nor that we are hastening the second coming of Christ.  I trust that, like the woman who cried on Jesus feet, like Paul who celebrated life knowing he should be dead, we are acutely aware of the depths of our own rebellion against the Lord. It doesn’t always take getting knocked off a horse to come to this realization, but it almost always takes something very like that.  At some point, if you haven’t yet, you will find yourself flat on your back looking up at the risen Christ.  What is your response?  I trust that you, like Paul, will find yourself eternally grateful that, while we cowered in a corner, Jesus reached down with his life, death and resurrection, and poured out a flood of cleansing grace and mercy over our retched and useless lives.  We are born again into newness of life, made co-participators of the divine nature, baptized into Christ’s body, and indwelt by the Holy Spirit.  How can that not compel us to be the best that we can be and give the best that we are in a love offering to this amazing God?   Remember that phone call I was struggling over making to extract our team from the troubled East Asia city? I realized I didn’t make that phone call to Pioneers, because those young people that are out there don’t belong to me.  They were released to God. They are exchanging that which they cannot keep, for that which they cannot lose.  How could I take that away from them?  There is no sacrifice in that.   Are you making that exchange with your choices? Don’t settle for your image in a carnival mirror.  Please don’t.  It might make you look good, but it is a lie from the pit. Look into the mirror of truth that is the person and word of Jesus Christ.  Be compelled with the wonder that you are still alive. You shouldn’t be, you know.  You really shouldn’t.  But if you can feel the waterfall of God’s mercy and grace cascading down on you, then I think you will find a way to celebrate that on a world stage.  You will find a way to involve yourself in God’s purposes for the nations. That road of service, whatever it looks like, whether it is praying, or giving or going, will be driven by many things, but primarily it will be driven by the love from God.

title: Nicene creed
content:
The Nicene Creed


I believe in one God, the Father Almighty, Maker of heaven and earth, and of all things visible and invisible.


And in one Lord Jesus Christ, the only-begotten Son of God, begotten of the Father before all worlds; God of God, Light of Light, very God of very God; begotten, not made, being of one substance with the Father, by whom all things were made.


Who, for us men and for our salvation, came down from heaven, and was incarnate by the Holy Spirit of the virgin Mary, and was made man; and was crucified also for us under Pontius Pilate; He suffered and was buried; and the third day He rose again, according to the Scriptures; and ascended into heaven, and sits on the right hand of the Father; and He shall come again, with glory, to judge the quick and the dead; whose kingdom shall have no end.


And I believe in the Holy Ghost, the Lord and Giver of Life; who proceeds from the Father and the Son; who with the Father and the Son together is worshipped and glorified; who spoke by the prophets.


And I believe in one holy catholic and apostolic Church. I acknowledge one baptism for the remission of sins; and I look for the resurrection of the dead, and the life of the world to come. Amen.

title: Rom 11:36
content:
Mary's note:  May I never praise God out of a sense of giving Him something, adding to Him from myself something He needs. I have nothing to give. All I have is from Him.  May I never praise Him seeking to get favor or an experience of joy. That is not giving but taking and feeling entittled to blessing.  Out of my poverty, out of complete dependence on Him, out of gratitude for His love for me, and including me in His work and purpose, and sheer awe about His person and character, I praise Him in wonder and awe.
But I do desire His presence, His Joy, His Spirit in fellowship with mine

title: The Fruit of the Spirit is Love
The Fruit of the Spirit is Love

"A great many of us try hard at times to love. We try to force ourselves to love, and I do not say that is wrong; it is better than nothing. But the end of it is always very sad. "I fail continually," such as one must confess. And what is the reason? The
content: A great many of us try hard at times to love. We try to force ourselves to love, and I do not say that is wrong; it is better than nothing. But the end of it is always very sad. "I fail continually," such as one must confess. And what is the reason? The reason is simply this:Because they have never learned to believe and accept the truth that the Holy Spirit can pour God's love into their heart.

title: "The love of God is always the love of God in its entirety, in its fullness as an indwelling power, a love of God to me that leaps back to Him in love, and overflows to my fellow-men in love-God's love to me, and my love to God, and my love to my fellow-m
content: The love of God is always the love of God in its entirety, in its fullness as an indwelling power, a love of God to me that leaps back to Him in love, and overflows to my fellow- men in love- God's love to me, and my love to God, and my love to my fellow- men. The three are one; you cannot separate them.

The point is that God's faithfulness should not be put to the test, but is rather a given.
(NET note). 
My thought: Satan was tempting Jesus to hurry up the path to glorification by making an early and ostentatious display of power, instead of trusting and following the Fathers timing and plan.
Malcolm Guite “ I was not sent to look down from above, it’s fear that sets these tests and proofs, not love. 
“ thanks be to God that Jesus, in resisting this temptation to spiritual loftiness and display, shows his solidarity once and for all with all of us, trusting himself to our flesh and blood so that we can trust our flesh and blood to him. He does not look down on us, but looks up with the humble eyes of the child of Bethlehem.

title: Luk 21:14 NA28 with Apparatus and Parsings
content:
g4304. προμελετάω promeletaō ; from 4253 and 3191; to premeditate:--
prepare beforehand(1).

Rehearse

http://www.instepwithjesus.org/closerwalk2-3a

But here is the central point in this conversation: To be afraid to meditate properly, because some others do it inappropriately (or even dangerously), is like being afraid to use the telephone in case you might get a wrong number. Meditation is an essential part of a balanced Christian life. “Draw near to God and He will draw near to you” (James 4:8). It’s a promise.2

https://bible.org/article/biblical-meditation

(4) Transformation—It is designed to transform and change our lives. This would apply to all the above (Ps. 4:4; 19:14; 119:15; Rom. 12:2; Col. 3:1f).

...

To prepare myself as a Christian psychiatrist, I undertook college studies, an M.S. degree in human physiology, an M.D. from medical school, psychiatric residency training in two different programs, and theological course ware from two evangelical seminaries. During those years I was equipped with many techniques and shortcuts for bringing human beings relief from anxieties, depression, phobias, fears, insecurities, and other kinds of emotional and physical pain. Among the many tools I learned to use, by far the one that has been most valuable in helping people attain spiritual well-being is Scripture meditation.3

Meditation affects man’s whole being. Another reason is the fact man does not innately contain God’s thoughts and ways. Again Meier writes:

Man is a totally depraved being, possessing selfish and ultimately self-destructive thought patterns and behavior. Show me a natural man, untaught in God’s principles and I’ll show you a natural man who suffers from emotional pain. I’ll show you a man who experiences the guilt and discomfort of a God-vacuum. I’ll show you a man who is unconsciously fighting and struggling for a sense of significance, using worldly ways (e.g., sexual fantasy, materialism, power struggles, and prestige) in a vain attempt to attain significance all of which will fail. The ways of the world bring temporary relief, like bandaids on open flesh wounds, but not ultimate relief from man’s inner awareness of his insignificance apart from God.4

title: Ezk 17:22-24 NASB Strong's Bible Text
content: I will also take a sprig from the lofty top of the cedar and set it out; I will pluck from the topmost of its young twigs a tender one and I will plant it on a high and lofty mountain. On the high mountain of Israel I will plant it, that it may bring forth boughs and bear fruit and become a stately cedar. And birds of every kind will nest under it; they will nest in the shade of its branches. All the trees of the field will know that I am the Lord; I bring down the high tree, exalt the low tree, dry up the green tree and make the dry tree flourish. I am the Lord; I have spoken, and I will perform it.”

title: Isa 11:1-10 NASB Strong's Bible Text
content:
Then a shoot will spring from the stem of Jesse,
And a branch from his roots will bear fruit.
The Spirit of the Lord will rest on Him,
The spirit of wisdom and understanding,
The spirit of counsel and strength,
The spirit of knowledge and the fear of the Lord.
And He will delight in the fear of the Lord,
And He will not judge by what His eyes see,
Nor make a decision by what His ears hear;
But with righteousness He will judge the poor,
And decide with fairness for the afflicted of the earth;
And He will strike the earth with the rod of His mouth,
And with the breath of His lips He will slay the wicked.
Also righteousness will be the belt about His loins,
And faithfulness the belt about His waist.
And the wolf will dwell with the lamb,
And the leopard will lie down with the young goat,
And the calf and the young lion and the fatling together;
And a little boy will lead them.
Also the cow and the bear will graze,
Their young will lie down together,
And the lion will eat straw like the ox.
The nursing child will play by the hole of the cobra,
And the weaned child will put his hand on the viper’s den.
They will not hurt or destroy in all My holy mountain,
For the earth will be full of the knowledge of the Lord
As the waters cover the sea.
Then in that day
The nations will resort to the root of Jesse,
Who will stand as a signal for the peoples;
And His resting place will be glorious.

title: Isa 4:2-6 NASB Strong's Bible Text
content: In that day the Branch of the Lord will be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the earth will be the pride and the adornment of the survivors of Israel. It will come about that he who is left in Zion and remains in Jerusalem will be called holy—everyone who is recorded for life in Jerusalem. When the Lord has washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion and purged the bloodshed of Jerusalem from her midst, by the spirit of judgment and the spirit of burning, then the Lord will create over the whole area of Mount Zion and over her assemblies a cloud by day, even smoke, and the brightness of a flaming fire by night; for over all the glory will be a canopy. There will be a shelter to give shade from the heat by day, and refuge and protection from the storm and the rain.

title: Jer 23:5-6 NASB Strong's Bible Text
content:
“Behold, the days are coming,” declares the Lord,
“When I will raise up for David a righteous Branch;
And He will reign as king and act wisely
And do justice and righteousness in the land.
“In His days Judah will be saved,
And Israel will dwell securely;
And this is His name by which He will be called,
‘The Lord our righteousness.’

title: Jer 33:15-18 NASB Strong's Bible Text
content: In those days and at that time I will cause a righteous Branch of David to spring forth; and He shall execute justice and righteousness on the earth. In those days Judah will be saved and Jerusalem will dwell in safety; and this is the name by which she will be called: the Lord is our righteousness.’ For thus says the Lord, ‘David shall never lack a man to sit on the throne of the house of Israel; and the Levitical priests shall never lack a man before Me to offer burnt offerings, to burn grain offerings and to prepare sacrifices continually.’”

title: Zch 3:8-10 NASB Strong's Bible Text
content: Now listen, Joshua the high priest, you and your friends who are sitting in front of you—indeed they are men who are a symbol, for behold, I am going to bring in My servant the Branch. For behold, the stone that I have set before Joshua; on one stone are seven eyes. Behold, I will engrave an inscription on it,’ declares the Lord of hosts, ‘and I will remove the iniquity of that land in one day. ‘In that day,’ declares the Lord of hosts, ‘every one of you will invite his neighbor to sit under his vine and under his fig tree.’”

title: Zch 6:12-15 NASB Strong's Bible Text
content: Thus says the Lord of hosts, “Behold, a man whose name is Branch, for He will branch out from where He is; and He will build the temple of the Lord. Yes, it is He who will build the temple of the Lord, and He who will bear the honor and sit and rule on His throne. Thus, He will be a priest on His throne, and the counsel of peace will be between the two offices.”’ Now the crown will become a reminder in the temple of the Lord to Helem, Tobijah, Jedaiah and Hen the son of Zephaniah. Those who are far off will come and build the temple of the Lord.” Then you will know that the Lord of hosts has sent me to you. And it will take place if you completely obey the Lord your God.

title: Pro 8:22-31 NASB Strong's Bible Text
content:
The Lord possessed me at the beginning of His way,
Before His works of old.
“From everlasting I was established,
From the beginning, from the earliest times of the earth.
“When there were no depths I was brought forth,
When there were no springs abounding with water.
“Before the mountains were settled,
Before the hills I was brought forth;
While He had not yet made the earth and the fields,
Nor the first dust of the world.
“When He established the heavens, I was there,
When He inscribed a circle on the face of the deep,
When He made firm the skies above,
When the springs of the deep became fixed,
When He set for the sea its boundary
So that the water would not transgress His command,
When He marked out the foundations of the earth;
Then I was beside Him, as a master workman;
And I was daily His delight,
Rejoicing always before Him,
Rejoicing in the world, His earth,
And having my delight in the sons of men.

title: Isa 42:1-9 NASB Strong's Bible Text
content:
“Behold, My Servant, whom I uphold;
My chosen one in whom My soul delights.
I have put My Spirit upon Him;
He will bring forth justice to the nations.
“He will not cry out or raise His voice,
Nor make His voice heard in the street.
“A bruised reed He will not break
And a dimly burning wick He will not extinguish;
He will faithfully bring forth justice.
“He will not be disheartened or crushed
Until He has established justice in the earth;
And the coastlands will wait expectantly for His law.”
Thus says God the Lord,
Who created the heavens and stretched them out,
Who spread out the earth and its offspring,
Who gives breath to the people on it
And spirit to those who walk in it,
“I am the Lord, I have called You in righteousness,
I will also hold You by the hand and watch over You,
And I will appoint You as a covenant to the people,
As a light to the nations,
To open blind eyes,
To bring out prisoners from the dungeon
And those who dwell in darkness from the prison.
“I am the Lord, that is My name;
I will not give My glory to another,
Nor My praise to graven images.
“Behold, the former things have come to pass,
Now I declare new things;
Before they spring forth I proclaim them to you

title: Isa 50:4-11 NASB Strong's Bible Text
content:
The Lord God has given Me the tongue of disciples,
That I may know how to sustain the weary one with a word.
He awakens Me morning by morning,
He awakens My ear to listen as a disciple.
The Lord God has opened My ear;
And I was not disobedient
Nor did I turn back.
I gave My back to those who strike Me,
And My cheeks to those who pluck out the beard;
I did not cover My face from humiliation and spitting.
For the Lord God helps Me,
Therefore, I am not disgraced;
Therefore, I have set My face like flint,
And I know that I will not be ashamed.
He who vindicates Me is near;
Who will contend with Me?
Let us stand up to each other;
Who has a case against Me?
Let him draw near to Me.
Behold, the Lord God helps Me;
Who is he who condemns Me?
Behold, they will all wear out like a garment;
The moth will eat them.
Who is among you that fears the Lord,
That obeys the voice of His servant,
That walks in darkness and has no light?
Let him trust in the name of the Lord and rely on his God.
Behold, all you who kindle a fire,
Who encircle yourselves with firebrands,
Walk in the light of your fire
And among the brands you have set ablaze.
This you will have from My hand:
You will lie down in torment.

title: Isa 52:13-52:12 NASB Strong's Bible Text
content:
The Exalted Servant
Behold, My servant will prosper,
He will be high and lifted up and greatly exalted.
Just as many were astonished at you, My people,
So His appearance was marred more than any man
And His form more than the sons of men.
Thus He will sprinkle many nations,
Kings will shut their mouths on account of Him;
For what had not been told them they will see,
And what they had not heard they will understand.
The Suffering Servant
Who has believed our message?
And to whom has the arm of the Lord been revealed?
For He grew up before Him like a tender shoot,
And like a root out of parched ground;
He has no stately form or majesty
That we should look upon Him,
Nor appearance that we should be attracted to Him.
He was despised and forsaken of men,
A man of sorrows and acquainted with grief;
And like one from whom men hide their face
He was despised, and we did not esteem Him.
Surely our griefs He Himself bore,
And our sorrows He carried;
Yet we ourselves esteemed Him stricken,
Smitten of God, and afflicted.
But He was pierced through for our transgressions,
He was crushed for our iniquities;
The chastening for our well-being fell upon Him,
And by His scourging we are healed.
All of us like sheep have gone astray,
Each of us has turned to his own way;
But the Lord has caused the iniquity of us all
To fall on Him.
He was oppressed and He was afflicted,
Yet He did not open His mouth;
Like a lamb that is led to slaughter,
And like a sheep that is silent before its shearers,
So He did not open His mouth.
By oppression and judgment He was taken away;
And as for His generation, who considered
That He was cut off out of the land of the living
For the transgression of my people, to whom the stroke was due?
His grave was assigned with wicked men,
Yet He was with a rich man in His death,
Because He had done no violence,
Nor was there any deceit in His mouth.
But the Lord was pleased
To crush Him, putting Him to grief;
If He would render Himself as a guilt offering,
He will see His offspring,
He will prolong His days,
And the good pleasure of the Lord will prosper in His hand.
As a result of the anguish of His soul,
He will see it and be satisfied;
By His knowledge the Righteous One,
My Servant, will justify the many,
As He will bear their iniquities.
Therefore, I will allot Him a portion with the great,
And He will divide the booty with the strong;
Because He poured out Himself to death,
And was numbered with the transgressors;
Yet He Himself bore the sin of many,
And interceded for the transgressors.

title: Jer 23:6 NASB Strong's
content:
Net Bible note:
is used for "vindication" in legal contexts (see, e.g., Job 6:29), for "deliverance" or "salvation" in exilic contexts (see, e.g., Isa 58:8), and in the sense of ruling, judging with "justice" (see, e.g., Lev 19:15; Isa 32:1). Here it probably sums up the justice that the Lord provides through raising up this ruler as well as the safety, security, and well-being that result (see vv. 5-6a). In the NT this takes on soteriological connotations (see 1 Cor 1:31 in its context).

title: Rom 8:3 NASB Strong's
content: In the Old Testament, the sin-offering is the sacrifice used when someone has committed sin unwittingly (not knowing it was wrong) or unwillingly (knowing it was wrong but not intending [willing] to do it). Paul has analysed the plight of Israel under the law in such a way that it falls exactly into these categories. ‘The good I want to do, I don’t do; the evil I don’t want is what I do.’ The ‘miserable person’ (Israel) of 7.24 is answered by God’s provision of the sin-offering in 8.3, just as, at a more general level, the condemned sinner of 1.18–3.20 is promised that there is ‘no condemnation’ for those who are ‘in the Messiah’, because the condemnation of sin has already taken place in him.. (N. T. Wright)

title: Eph 1:1 NASB Strong’s (Lockman)
content:
ἅγιος
STRONG’S NUMBER:g0040
Dictionary Definition g0040. ἅγιος hagios ; from a prim. root; sacred, holy:--
Holy(92), holy(62), Holy of Holies(1), holy one(5), holy ones(1), holy place(7), most holy(1), saint(1), saints(59), saints'(1), sanctuary(2).

Something or someone set apart for God.

Wikipedia:

Other Protestantism
In many Protestant churches, the word saint is used more generally to refer to anyone who is a Christian. This is similar in usage to Paul's numerous references in the New Testament of the Bible. In this sense, anyone who is within the Body of Christ (i.e., a professing Christian) is a saint because of their relationship with Christ Jesus. Many Protestants consider intercessory prayers to the saints to be idolatry, since what they perceive to be an application of divine worship that should be given only to God himself is being given to other believers, dead or alive.

Within some Protestant traditions, saint is also used to refer to any born-again Christian. Many emphasize the traditional New Testament meaning of the word, preferring to write "saint" to refer to any believer, in continuity with the doctrine of the priesthood of all believers.

title: Jn 1:49 NASB Strong’s (Lockman)
content: Nathanael's confession - You are the Son of God; you are the King of Israel - is best understood as a confession of Jesus' messiahship. It has strong allusions to Ps 2:6-7, a well-known messianic psalm. What Nathanael's exact understanding was at this point is hard to determine, but "son of God" was a designation for the Davidic king in the OT, and Nathanael parallels it with King of Israel here

title: Jn 1:51
content: The title Son of Man appears 13 times in John's Gospel. It is associated especially with the themes of crucifixion (3:14; 8:28), revelation (6:27; 6:53), and eschatological authority (5:27; 9:35). The title as used in John's Gospel has for its background the son of man figure who appears in Dan 7:13-14 and is granted universal regal authority. Thus for the author, the emphasis in this title is not on Jesus' humanity, but on his heavenly origin and divine authority.

title: Jn 17:17
content: The Greek word translated set apart (ἁγιάζω, hagiazo) is used here in its normal sense of being dedicated, consecrated, or set apart. The sphere in which the disciples are to be set apart is in the truth. In 3:21 the idea of "practicing" (Grk "doing") the truth was introduced; in 8:32 Thus Jesus can ask the Father to set them apart in this truth as he himself is set apart, so that they might carry on his mission in the world after his departure (note the following verse).

title: Jn 17:19
content: meaning is closer to the consecration of a sacrificial animal (Deut 15:19). Jesus is "setting himself apart," i.e., dedicating himself, to do the will of the Father, that is, to go to the cross on the disciples' behalf (and of course on behalf of their successors as well). From NET Bible notes.

title: Phi 2:5
content: Tom Wright notices that Paul’s plea for unity among his friends in Philippi is only “achieved by actively cultivating certain virtues, particularly those connected with learning to think… as Jesus thought. Their union with [Jesus] is the ground for such character-development, however counter-intuitive this was in Greco-Roman culture.”*

title: Psa 51:4 NASB Strong’s (Lockman)
content:
David fully realized that his sin (adultery, murder, corruption, denial) was not just against Bathsheba and Uriah, but against God Almighty. Ultimately, it is God that we need forgiveness from.   

God is all goodness and the source of it all.  We sin against His creation and His very nature.  We are rebels against the King.

Pulpit commentaries:

https://www.studylight.org/commentaries/eng/tpc/psalms-51.html

Against thee, thee only, have I sinned. Though no sins could be more directly against man than adultery and murder, yet David feels that that aspect of them shrinks away into insignificance, and is as if it were not, when they are viewed in their true and real character, as offences against the majesty of God. Every sin is mainly against God; and the better sort of men always feel this. "How can I do this great wickedness," says Joseph, when tempted by Potiphar's wife, "and sin against God?" And so David to Nathan, when he was first rebuked by him, "I have sinned against the Lord" (2 Samuel 12:13). And done this evil in thy sight; that thou mightest be justified when thou speakest, and be clear when thou judgest. Clear in the eyes of the world, that is; free from all charge of harshness or injustice, when thou judgest me, and condemnest me for my sins, as thou must do.

There is no one greater in this house than I, and he has withheld nothing from me except you, because you are his wife. How then could I do this great evil and sin against God?”
